section_01.section_summary: The city of Nacogdoches has a rich history dating back to the time of the Tejas Indians, who settled in the area and built homes around ceremonial mounds. According to legend, the city was founded by Nacogdoches, one of the twin sons of a Caddo chief, who was instructed to travel towards the setting sun and establish a home. The area was later visited by European explorers, including Hernando De Soto and LaSalle, and was also influenced by the ministrations of Mother Maria de Jesus de Agreda, who taught the Tejas tribes the Christian religion. The first permanent European settlement in Nacogdoches was established in 1716 with the founding of the Mission Nuestra Senora de Guadalupe de Nacogdoches, and the city was later refounded by Captain Antonio Gil Ybarbo in 1779. Over time, the city has evolved from an Indian town to a Spanish town, with a complex history shaped by the interactions of Native Americans, Europeans, and other cultures.

section_02.section_summary: The eastern boundary of Texas was unclear during the time of Gil Ybarbo, a Spanish leader who built "The Old Stone Fort" as a commissary for military and commercial supplies. Ybarbo governed the area as a benevolent despot, but was eventually removed from office due to irregularities and illegal activities. In 1800, the town of Nacogdoches remained loyal to Spain and helped suppress Philip Nolan's expedition, which was backed by American leaders James Wilkinson and Aaron Burr. Nolan's expedition was defeated, and its members were captured and imprisoned in the Old Stone Fort before being taken to Mexico. The purchase of Louisiana by the United States from France at the start of the 19th century brought significant changes to the political and military affairs of Nacogdoches, leading to increased tensions and a territorial dispute between the two countries.
